**Feedback & Actionable Edit Instructions (compact paragraph)**  
Your draft touches on the right themes but falls short of a world‑class, first‑principles analysis. 1) **Causal chain & market transmission**: explicitly map how the soy moratorium shifts Brazil’s supply curve (ΔQs ≈ –15 % for Amazon‑derived soy), tightens terms of trade (TT‑ΔP ≈ +2 % for soy), and feeds into Brazil’s real‑rate differential (rB – rUS ≈ +0.5 pp) and BoP (exports ↑ $10 bn, net external position improves). Cite the 344 % cultivation surge and 69 % deforestation drop (J54PXL0NV) and add soybean price data (e.g., 2024 average $1.20/lb). 2) **Japanese banks**: quantify the expected inflow (e.g., $200 bn of foreign‑asset management capital), link to yen depreciation (Δ¥ ≈ –3 %) and JPY yield curve steepening (Δy10‑y2 ≈ +0.3 pp). Reference the $1.3 trillion AUM (PA57YBYVQ) and include the policy reaction function of BOJ (e.g., “if foreign inflows > $50 bn, BOJ tightens by 0.25 %”). 3) **Fed & dollar**: replace vague “under pressure” with quantitative expectations (e.g., 10‑year Treasury yield target 2.5 % ± 0.25 pp, dollar index Δ ≈ –1.5 % post‑Jackson Hole). Cite the 79 % probability of a cut (IBGK2IRII) and the 15 % EU tariff (IBGK2IRII). 4) **Geopolitical risk**: model the Ukraine‑sanctions shock as a 5 % rise in global risk‑premium (σ ≈ +0.2 pp) and its spill‑over to commodity prices (soy +3 %, oil +4 %). Reference the Trump‑Putin summit details (G47IHVUJK) and note the potential for a “sanctions reset” scenario. 5) **Scenario structure & catalysts**: create a 3‑scenario matrix (Base, Fed‑tightening, Ukraine‑sanctions) with explicit trigger dates (e.g., Jackson Hole, summit outcome, court ruling). 6) **Citation density**: add inline IDs for every quantitative claim (e.g., J54PXL0NV, PA57YBYVQ, IBGK2IRII, G47IHVUJK). 7) **Clarity & coherence**: rewrite the paragraph into a logical flow: start with Brazil, move to Japan, then U.S. dollar, finish with geopolitical risk, ending with a concise base‑case, risks, and watch list. 8) **Avoid generic platitudes**: replace “under pressure” with “expected to fall 1.5 %” and “tightening risk” with “potential 0.5 pp rise in 10‑yr yields.” 9) **First‑principles grounding**: explicitly state the underlying economic theory (e.g., supply‑side constraint → higher terms of trade → real‑rate differential). 10) **Coverage of all critical sources**: ensure every claim is backed by at least one source ID; if a source is missing, add a new citation or remove the claim.  

Implement these edits to transform the draft into a rigorous, data‑driven, multi‑year structural analysis that meets the SECTION FOCUS criteria.
